annotation.TEXT: Sadly, you can't exactly cruise through the second laser area. Some of the platforms have been stretched out to counter Cut Man's speed boost. It basically makes the latter half feel more or less the same as vanilla Quick Man's (save for the drop into the second screen, where it's very easy to mess up and run right into a laser thanks to the small space you need to maneuver around).

Any changes to the stage layouts are pretty few and far between in this hack. Generally though, the modifications typically boil down to huge gaps that you'd never be able to make in a normal hack. "Pekechu's" stage has what's probably one of the more significant changes, in that it completely removes the need to do that long block puzzle towards the end.

Speaking of things that barely anyone remembers, here's Kangaroo Jack. I never saw the film before, but going off the trailer (and the fact that the movie has incredibly negative reviews), I don't think I missed out on much. Either way, we're still dealing with those lasers in this stage.
And the award for most terrifying sprite in the hack goes to...

Not Metal Man (I seriously have no idea what the actual spelling of this thing's name is) is made a bit more annoying by the whole one bullet restriction. Then again, seeing as this is basically just MM2 with a new (read: terrible) coat of paint, the Metal Blades are still just as much of a top priority as they've always been.

With that being said, here's a brief warning: If flashing lights make you uneasy in any way, you might want to stop the video now. This hack has quite a few instances of flashing effects, most of which come with absolutely terrible palette choices (and nowhere is that more exemplified than in the first stage).

It feels like it's been a while since I've even heard mention of Carrot Top. Referencing him alone seems kinda dated at this point, but Jason Hayes went the extra mile and included a nod to those "1-800-CALL-ATT" commercials that Carrot Top used to be in all the time. That's honestly the last thing I'd expect a ROM hack to remind me of.

Absolutely majestic, isn't it? In any case, here's the basic run-down: This is essentially MM2 with speed hacks. Cut Man moves much faster and jumps higher than Mega Man, to the point where he's a bit unwieldy in some sections. Aside from the speed boost, your buster is set to auto-fire if you hold down the button. While having the potential to be overpowered, it also has a major trade-off: You can only have one shot on-screen at a time instead of the usual three.

For those of you that still have any brain cells left after all that, then let me to welcome you to "Cutman's Bad Scizzors Day." It was created by Jason "Godman" Hayes, and it is - to put it bluntly - the pinnacle of bad MM2 hacks. I don't necessarily mean that in a bad way, either. In fact, this hack is actually a lot more tolerable than most run-of-the-mill MM2 modifications, if you can believe it.

Another thing to consider: For anyone who's played MM2 with a turbo controller or auto-fire, you'd also know that it's...not exactly 100% reliable. The turbo fire in this game has a tendency to just flat out not work sometimes. This mostly happens underwater (for some reason), and when there's too many sprites on-screen (the Hot Dogs in Wood Man's stage being a prime offender in those regards).

Crash Bombs (or rather, "Doom ina can") have had their ammo count significantly boosted in this hack. I still don't see them as viable, but at the very least, it makes the Boobeam Trap a bit more manageable (barring Cut Man's absurd speed).

The fight with Kangaroo Jack himself is...well, actually really annoying. The one-shot limit on the buster is the primary reason for this, along with the two extra blocks that have been added to the upper right and left of the room (making the boss leap all over the place as a result).

As implied before, the weapons haven't really changed (aside from one). The only thing that's generally new here are their names, and some of them are....well, you'll see. The numbered items in particular are something special though (not so much because of their names, but rather, the whole "get item" sequence itself).

"Ten outta ten, best sprite." In all seriousness though, it's been a long, long time since I've seen Jackie Chan Adventures. If anything, that's one thing this hack has going for it: It's got a reminder of a neat cartoon series from way back when. Then again, that's far from the most dated reference this hack has to offer.

I'm pretty sure I've referenced "I WILL GRRRR!" in my past videos before. So for those of you who were wondering what that was all about, now you know: It comes from an intentionally nonsensical ROM hack from 2008 (at least, I'm pretty sure that's when this was made).
